translated: The Mansion on the Plane of the Gods
The Male Person
The Great Charioteers
The First Discourse on the Needle-Reed Palace
“This lofty mansion, a jewel-pillar,

analyzed: samantataḥ dvādasa yojanāni  kūṭāgārā satta satā uḷārā
translated: Twelve leagues all around,🔽With seven hundred upper rooms,
With pillars of cat’s eye gem, well-roofed, beautiful.
There you live, drink, & eat,
And divine, lovely lutes play music.

analyzed: dibbāḥ rasāḥ kāma guṇā ittha pañca
translated: Divine flavors, the five strands of pleasure here,
And women dance, covered in gold.
By what is your beauty so great?

analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ ca te sabbadisā pabhāsati iti
translated: And your beauty shines in all directions?”
The god, pleased,
is the fruit of that action.

original: “Yaṁ dadāti na taṁ hoti,🔽Yañceva dajjā tañceva seyyo;
analyzed: yam dadāti na tam hoti  yat ca iva dajjā tat ca iva seyyaḥ
translated: “What you give is not what it is,🔽And what you should give is better.
A needle given is better than a needle.
By that your beauty is so great,

analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ ca me sabbadisā pabhāsati iti
translated: And my beauty shines in all directions.”
The First Discourse on the Needle-Reed Palace, the eighth.
